title: How to Make Mochi Pizza

steps.headline: Cut two or three blocks of kirimochi (切り餅) or kakumochi (角餅) into 1-inch slices.
steps.description: Be sure to use kirimochi or kakumochi, which are hard and square, and not marumochi (丸餅), which are round and fluffier.

steps.headline: Heat one tablespoon of neutral oil in a wok or nonstick skillet over medium heat.
steps.description: Use a neutral oil like vegetable or canola oil, although you can also use olive oil.

steps.headline: Assemble mochi pieces in the hot pan in the shape of your pizza.
steps.description: As they cook, the mochi will melt slightly, forming the "dough" of your pizza. Arrange them into the shape you ultimately want the dough to be before they start melting. Try forming a square, a circle, a rectangle, or even a triangle with your mochi.

steps.headline: Gently brown the mochi for 2 to 3 minutes over medium heat.
steps.description: When the bottom of mochi begins to get sticky, proceed to the next step.

steps.headline: Pour ¼ cup water into the bottom of the wok or skillet and cover with a lid.
steps.description: This will begin to steam-cook the mochi and cause it to coalesce even move. Cook, covered, for 2 to 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Flip the mochi with a spatula and brown the other side for 2 to 3 minutes.
Uncover the wok or skillet and add your pizza sauce.
steps.description: With a ladle or spoon, coat the top of the mochi dough with sauce. The sauce can be actual pizza sauce or something like ketchup.

steps.headline: Add toppings.
steps.description:
The sky is the limit when thinking about toppings. Try the followings for ideas:
Green peas, thin pork belly, or bean sprouts for a Japanese twist
Scallions, shrimp, and corn for another okonomiyaki-style treat
Green peppers, fennel, and sausage
Salami, pepperoni, and sausage for a meat-lover's delight

steps.headline: Add enough cheese to cover.
steps.description: Choose your cheese wisely. With stronger-tasting toppings, you'll want a bland cheese. With subtler-tasting toppings, you may want a strong cheese.

steps.headline: Cover your mochi pizza and continue to cook for 2 to 3 minutes, until cheese is melted.
steps.description: If you like your cheese extra gooey and slightly browned on top, stick the mochi pizza in a toaster oven or under the broiler for a minute.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: You've probably made the most interesting "pizza" in town — maybe even in your country!

text:
Cut two or three blocks of kirimochi (切り餅) or kakumochi (角餅) into 1-inch slices. Be sure to use kirimochi or kakumochi, which are hard and square, and not marumochi (丸餅), which are round and fluffier. Heat one tablespoon of neutral oil in a wok or nonstick skillet over medium heat. Use a neutral oil like vegetable or canola oil, although you can also use olive oil. Assemble mochi pieces in the hot pan in the shape of your pizza. As they cook, the mochi will melt slightly, forming the "dough" of your pizza. Arrange them into the shape you ultimately want the dough to be before they start melting. Try forming a square, a circle, a rectangle, or even a triangle with your mochi. Gently brown the mochi for 2 to 3 minutes over medium heat. When the bottom of mochi begins to get sticky, proceed to the next step. Pour ¼ cup water into the bottom of the wok or skillet and cover with a lid. This will begin to steam-cook the mochi and cause it to coalesce even move. Cook, covered, for 2 to 3 minutes. Flip the mochi with a spatula and brown the other side for 2 to 3 minutes.  Uncover the wok or skillet and add your pizza sauce. With a ladle or spoon, coat the top of the mochi dough with sauce. The sauce can be actual pizza sauce or something like ketchup. Add toppings. The sky is the limit when thinking about toppings. Try the followings for ideas:
Green peas, thin pork belly, or bean sprouts for a Japanese twist
Scallions, shrimp, and corn for another okonomiyaki-style treat
Green peppers, fennel, and sausage
Salami, pepperoni, and sausage for a meat-lover's delight Add enough cheese to cover. Choose your cheese wisely. With stronger-tasting toppings, you'll want a bland cheese. With subtler-tasting toppings, you may want a strong cheese. Cover your mochi pizza and continue to cook for 2 to 3 minutes, until cheese is melted. If you like your cheese extra gooey and slightly browned on top, stick the mochi pizza in a toaster oven or under the broiler for a minute. Serve. You've probably made the most interesting "pizza" in town — maybe even in your country!
